docs.lead_paragraph: A clown came to a day care center on this Army post to pass out balloons on a warm day not long ago. The children, balloon strings tied around their wrists, squealed and dashed about a grassy yard. A bit later, to the sound of tiny hands clapping, a delivery boy brought pizzas for lunch. The center, one of several like it on military bases around the nation, was an example of the steps the Army has taken recently to help troubled families cope with the pressures and tensions of modern Army life. The cheerful scene masked the fact that the two dozen children in the center had been abused by their parents, sometimes severely. Child abuse is but one product of the strains of military life today, according to officers here and in Washington. Those stresses, which include repeated moves, long separations and inadequate housing, have led to violence, alcoholism, drug abuse, vandalism, abandoned families, financial mismanagement and debt.

headline.main: ARMY ACTS TO HELP FAMILIES COPE WITH PRESSURES OF MODERN MILITARY LIFE
